speaker: candidate
text: Yeah, overall I really enjoy collaborative environments. I think good teamwork is what makes projects succeed, and I always try to bring positive energy.

speaker: candidate
text: In my last role, I was responsible for maintaining the CI pipeline. I honestly learned a lot from more senior folks on the team.

speaker: candidate
text: I mean… sometimes the reviews were a bit nitpicky, but it's fine, I guess. I usually appreciate constructive feedback.

speaker: candidate
text: I've been working professionally for about five years now. Mostly backend-focused, with a bit of DevOps mixed in.

speaker: candidate
text: One project went a bit sideways, but that wasn't really on me. The product requirements kept shifting every week.

speaker: candidate
text: I do admit though, I could have communicated earlier that the deadlines were unrealistic. That's something I'm improving.

speaker: candidate
text: I really like mentoring junior teammates. Helping people grow helps me grow too.

speaker: candidate
text: I've always been pretty detail-oriented. I test my stuff thoroughly so I don't block others.

speaker: candidate
text: Honestly though, sometimes people don't follow instructions well and it slows me down. But anyway, teamwork is important.

speaker: candidate
text: I try to stay curious and learn new tools every quarter. Last year I picked up Rust just to explore new patterns.

speaker: candidate
text: So yeah, overall I'd say I have around three years of real backend experience. The first two years weren't full-time, more like internships and small gigs.

speaker: candidate
text: Culture matters a lot to me. I hate environments where people blame each other instead of focusing on solutions.

speaker: candidate
text: I mean, except in rare cases where someone just doesn't pull their weight, you know? It happens.

speaker: candidate
text: I'm generally pretty humble, I think. I know I don't have the answers to everything.

speaker: candidate
text: But to be fair, I usually know the best approach on backend decisions. I've seen enough patterns to know what works.

speaker: candidate
text: My last company was a startup of about thirty people. Lots of autonomy, lots of learning.

speaker: candidate
text: The CTO relied on me because I was basically the most experienced backend engineer there.

speaker: candidate
text: Oh—although actually, this was technically my first real backend job. Before that I was mostly doing school projects and no real professional development work.

speaker: candidate
text: But yeah, I'm excited to grow more and work with strong engineering teams.

speaker: candidate
text: And I'm always happy to admit mistakes if it helps the team move faster.
